description.narrative: Output 1.4: Alternative education system for most vulnerable children established and operational

System strengthening - responsiveness of education/training system to the labour market

related-activity.ref: 2740/A0/06/881 EQUITABLE AND QUALITY SOCIAL SERVICES FO

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 1.4: Alternative education system for most vulnerable children established and operational

description.narrative: The first-ever draft non-formal education policy was developed by MoE and UNICEF to establish learning and skills development systems for young out-of-school children and adolescents, ffollowing successful advocacy efforts by UNICEF. The piloted alternative education programme initiated by UNICEF and the Maldives Red Crescent benefited a total of 25 at-risk young boys (23) and girls (2) in southern Maldives, providing the young adolescents a second chance to develop basic literacy skills, acquire core life-skill competencies, and enroll in skills-development programmes such as water sports and electric wiring. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:10/12/2019

title.narrative: % of children accessing and learning through alternative education programs
System Strengthening - Gender - Existence of a school re-entry policy/strategy for pregnant girls and/or adolescent mothers - score (1-4), see guidance

target.value: 2018:No of children out of school benefitting from life skills programs and alternative learning programs

title.narrative: Service Delivery - Skills - Number of children who have participated in skills development programmes for learning, personal empowerment, active citizenship and/or employability through UNICEF-supported programmes

target.value: 2020:No of children reached with alternative learning

actual.value: 2019:By end of 2019, a total of 25 at-risk adolescents (23 males and 2 females) who were in conflict with the law and out of school in Addu City were identified and enrolled in an alternative learning and skills development program supported by UNICEF.
